channel.title: Trap producers. Where are the vocals/lyrics?
channel.description:
Trap is not a genre I listen to, but hearing the trap produced here, it's almost always instrumental only.
It's got me wondering…
  What we know… * Most, close to all, Trap music make by members here is instrumental / beats only. * Vocal tracks get loads more traction than instrumentals – in fact, many tracks don't feel finished until they have a vocal. * Rappers and trap vocalists are easy to find. There are loads on the usual music communities, incl. BandLab, SoundCloud, etc…
  So, question(s)…
* Are you actively looking for rappers / trap vocalists, but haven't found ones you want to work with? * Why aren't you releasing your trap beats as 'finished' tracks, and maximising the chances of getting traction? * Is there much of an audience for trap instrumentals – Have any trap instrumentals become successful?

item.title: Trap producers. Where are the vocals/lyrics?
item.dc:creator: INDIR3CT
item.description:
ThoughtfulNoise:

So, I’m trying to encourage that be giving the Trap producers here a nudge

Oh man. Absolutely… opening up to artists would… honestly help an Auxy artists growth SO much. And I appreciate those points being brought out. I hope a few of my answers could give a bit clearer pictures as to why some artists (including myself honestly) haven’t reached out quite yet

Read full topic
item.source: Trap producers. Where are the vocals/lyrics?

item.title: Trap producers. Where are the vocals/lyrics?
item.dc:creator: ThoughtfulNoise
item.description:
Maland2016:

Have we forgotten Marshmello already?

Chris may have moved a bit from that style, but his stuff is definitely well known. Tracks like most of Joytime I (and a couple off of II and III) as well as Colour, Pro, Wrong, etc, have little to no vocals, most of them just being a little hype phrase before the drop.

As mentioned, I’m no trap aficionado (and never was a listener of marshmello), but other than tempo, I’d say those reference tracks bear little relation to Trap, and are spiritually much closer to chart EDM.

They were likely made popular by EDM listeners, rather than Trap listeners.

The Trap instrumentals that seem to be made by Auxians — and the kind I’m talking about — is closer to the original 808 basslines, hi-hat runs and rap/mumble rap sound from Atlanta.

Read full topic
item.source: Trap producers. Where are the vocals/lyrics?

item.title: Trap producers. Where are the vocals/lyrics?
item.dc:creator: ThoughtfulNoise
item.description:
Ultimately, the points I’ve been trying to get across…

  1. Trap tracks with vocals appear to attract vastly more listens/listeners than instrumentals
  2. Finding and working with trap vocalists/rappers is relatively easy (and doesn’t need to cost any money)
  3. Auxy Trap producers would likely attract more listeners if they completed their tracks with a rap vocal

So, I’m trying to encourage that be giving the Trap producers here a nudge.

 
Done now

Read full topic

item.source: Trap producers. Where are the vocals/lyrics?

item.title: Trap producers. Where are the vocals/lyrics?
item.dc:creator: INDIR3CT
item.description:
ThoughtfulNoise:

Are people here paying their collaborative co-producers? Are they paying for vocal collaborators?
Why would rap collaborators be any different?

  1. Usually no… since collaborations via Auxy are so easy to execute (comparatively) they are all free (that I know of)
  2. Once in a while you will see a payed vocal service here and there.
  3. They wouldn’t be any different… just there isn’t really a lot of that type of vocal collaborators here in the Auxy community.
ThoughtfulNoise:

Do their parents know they collab with people using PMs here? Not sure I see a real difference.

  1. Haha… That’s not my place to answer. Collaborations via Auxy are… pretty small and simple… and not as… what’s the word. Professional of serious as a vocal collaboration. I know a few producers who’s collaborations I was in were cut off due to parents finding out about it. So that could a problem.
ThoughtfulNoise:

Are there any ‘hit’ instrumental trap tracks?

  1. Oh yes… yes there is. Within the Auxy community some of the best and most popular tracks made in Auxy history are classified as “trap”. Outside the Auxy community… the trap community is very large. Consider the record label empire “The Nations”… the largest section of the Nations is Trap Nation. Which is currently just shy of 30 million subscribers, and 11 billion views on YouTube alone. Not to mention other sectors of the Nations that include trap such and Chill and Bass Nation.

Instrumental trap these days is becoming less of a “trap/rap beat” and more of a heavier genre of electronic music… not so much EDM no… but very unique… that’s why I love it so much. It’s distinct. Very distinct.

Read full topic

item.source: Trap producers. Where are the vocals/lyrics?

item.title: Trap producers. Where are the vocals/lyrics?
item.dc:creator: ThoughtfulNoise
item.description:
INDIR3CT:

to creat a beat that is substantial on its own without vocals? Something that catches enough attention as something in the EDM world? That’s… when your “beat” turns into a real “track”. That’s when you can prove yourself as a producer.

I’m coming back to this one…

Are there any ‘hit’ instrumental trap tracks?

I came from the position that it simply wasn’t a genre that worked for instrumentals.
But now I’m wondering… well, why can’t it be? Surely it’s possibly to make a trap instrumental track that can hold its own and appeal to listeners without a vocal.

(I’m not talking about something at the same general bpm as trap, but something intentionally, recognisably trap – but instrumental, that achieved some level of success.)

Read full topic

item.source: Trap producers. Where are the vocals/lyrics?

item.title: Trap producers. Where are the vocals/lyrics?
item.dc:creator: ThoughtfulNoise
item.description:
INDIR3CT:

Him, and many others here on the Disco are young and can’t pay for a vocalist

Are people here paying their collaborative co-producers? Are they paying for vocal collaborators?
Why would rap collaborators be any different?

Many that approached me when I joined Bandlab were simply looking for people to collab with. No payment involved.

If you’d want to decide what the rapper raps about, or direct their style, etc… then, yeah, you’re basically using them to complete your idea, so they might expect to be paid something in the absence of equal creative freedom. Though maybe not.

If it’s a straight-up collab, then it’s not hard to find rappers who want to collab for free or for the cross-promotion.

Of course, YMMV when it comes to quality. You’re likely to find people for free who are new and not yet established. Still, that might be enough to help turn your trap tracks into their ultimate form.

(You don’t have to pick the first one you find.)

…or their parents might not appreciate them going out and reaching out to upcoming rappers.

Totally get your point, but…
Do their parents know they collab with people using PMs here? Not sure I see a real difference.

Read full topic

item.source: Trap producers. Where are the vocals/lyrics?

item.title: Trap producers. Where are the vocals/lyrics?
item.dc:creator: INDIR3CT
item.description:
There are a lot of ways to define trap, so I’ll try and keep it simple. All modern rap… is technically trap. Even though mainstream is still considered “hip hop” technically hip hop has a bpm consistently around 90… more of your old school boom bap rap. Trap is a sub genre of hip hop that is basically just a higher bpm. Typically, a trap beat is defined as having a BPM around 145, with hi-hats at a double or triple-time or faster. Any mainstream “rap” you hear on the radio is trap. It’s the more modern sub genre of hip hop. What you hear around here… in the auxy community are trap beats, that haven’t been able to reach vocals.

To answer some of your questions… it’s basically clout. Being able to create a “trap beat” is one thing but to creat a beat that is substantial on its own without vocals? Something that catches enough attention as something in the EDM world? That’s… when your “beat” turns into a real “track”. That’s when you can prove yourself as a producer.

It’s not hard at all to put lyrics onto a beat… it’s not that hard to do in Auxy either just it… takes… Time… And most of the passive hobbyists here are just… here to have fun (myself included). We don’t necessarily want to go into the time, effort, or funds to get a decent vocalist. You could attempt to record yourself but that’s always a pain because not many of us here have or have access to a proper recording studio… or even a reliable mic. (I’m not just talking about earbud mics or some nice desk gaming mic… a true recording mic costs a pretty penny. So I could imagine that’s another reason why there aren’t that many lyrics on top of beats currently.

Another issue lies with Auxy… sure you CAN put lyrics into Auxy but then again you are limited to 20 seconds per sample… so one would have to go into the hassle of properly trimming each vocal loop into the appropriate sizes… which then again takes time and skill.

One last thing I might point out is… just putting together a “trap beat” is… honestly fairly simple. Repetitive drum pattern, simple 808 or Reese bass melody… then your choice of simple chords, melody… or both. So for some people, they might just choose to stick with simple tracks they can make often to keep their activity high… and hope a few of their tracks are a “hit”.

So yeah… sorry for all this but I hope it clarifies a few things

Read full topic
